content.description:
Start in a dirty hand crack and plug a 2” cam or just stick clip the 1st bolt about 18ft off the ground if you don’t have gear. Follow the bolt line through a thin layback crack with a finger jam or two up to an obvious roof. The crux is from the 3rd bolt to the 5th bolt through powerful moves over the mini roof on holds way worse than they look from the ground. After your over the roof the climb eases up. The anchor is only 2 hangers and webbing that is past being usable  so we left 1 beiner on one of the hangers. I will go back up there soon to install some mussys but be prepared to leave a beiner or quick link until then.

If anyone has info on the FA party or the name I’ll update it immediately.
content.protection: A 2” piece to protect the initial crack moves and 7-8 draws for the upper part of the route.
content.location: Located on opposite side of the corridor from Flappy and RCM.

content.description:
Since the route begins in a narrow corridor, it is possible to stem the start, then move out on the face after the second bolt or so. The rest of the route clocks in at 5.10c.

HOWEVER,

the start certainly goes without stemming, and offers some very powerful crimping with very poor feet (5.11d/5.12a).

climbs.name: Flappy
climbs.fa: Mike Strassman, Jackie Carroll, and Steve Kabala

content.description:
This is a thin and challenging face climb.

The crux is found in the lower section.  Once you're past the 3rd bolt and the angle backs off, the climbing does, too, although it's still interesting.  A stick clip is handy, especially with the crux being low on the route. Another great Strassman, Carroll, et al route!  This route is in shade until about 1pm and probably doesn't get much sun at all from late fall to early spring.
content.protection: Ample bolts. Fat hooks for lowering.
content.location: This is the first route you encounter as you walk up to the Hangin' Tree after coming through the tunnel.  It follows the rounded prow of the buttress. RCM is in the corridor to the left.
